Award.AwardTitle: CMG: Nonlinear Elastic-Wave Inverse Scattering and Tomography - from Cracks to Mantle Convection
Award.AbstractNarration:
Knowing Earth?s internal structure on a range of length scales is necessary to understand natural hazards (earthquakes, volcanoes), exploit subsurface energy resources, and understand the long-term geological evolution of our planet. Seismic waves emitted by earthquakes or man-made sources represent the most direct and precise probes of Earth?s interior. Traditionally, seismologists recognize two types of non-destructive method for determining medium properties from measurements made at its boundary. Tomography (which in concept is similar to medical computer-aided tomography) aims to constrain smooth medium variations from transmitted seismic waves, whereas inverse scattering aims to constrain non-smooth heterogeneity (edges, interfaces) from reflected, refracted, or diffracted waves. These methods have revolutionized our understanding of Earth?s structure but have not yet reached their full potential. An important issue is that for practical and technical reasons they used to be treated separately. Indeed, (local) linearization and the use of asymptotic theory prevent internally consistent interpretation of seismic data with different (but complementary) sampling properties.
Building on expertise in seismology, inverse theory, and microlocal and harmonic analysis, the proposed research aims to develop a unified theoretical framework for (nonlinear, full wave) inversion and medium reconstruction, where tomography and inverse scattering are no longer treated separately. The new methods can lead to more accurate seismic exploration for oil and gas but the main geoscience motivation is to study the crust and mantle beneath North America with data provided by USArray, the seismology component of EarthScope, a nationwide, multi-year geosciences project funded by NSF.

From a mathematical sciences perspective the challenge is to develop a unified analysis of and computationally efficient algorithms for full wave inversion of the elastic wave equation and Cauchy or partial boundary data (here, broad-band waveforms measured at Earth?s surface). The proposed research extends the PIs previous research on inverse scattering and multi-scale tomography; it aims to transition from inverse scattering with the (asymptotic) generalized Radon transform to a full waveform analogue, to develop a nonlinear illumination correction and partial reconstruction approach and a (complementary) analyses for the (transient) time-domain formulation and (multi-)frequency (?fixed energy?) formulation, and to study wave constituents associated with (multiple) scattering off complex structures (edges, for example). In view of application to USArray data we aim to generalize receiver function analysis, characterize sharp transitions (such as the crust-mantle interface, the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary, and interfaces associated with subduction zones), and develop nonlinear reflection and transmission tomography to constrain physical properties of the mantle beneath North America.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the main parts of this project was a joint project with Gunther Uhlmann, and later with Plamen Stefanov. The question we studied is called invertibility for the geodesic X-ray transform: `can one find a function if we know its integral along geodesics?' --- the latter are curves along which waves such as light or earthquake waves travel. When the geodesics are straight lines, this is well-known, and it is used in CT scanners every day: the amount of X-ray traveling through a body corresponds to this integral. This invertibility problem in turn is closely related to boundary rigidity, which for an elastic body (such as the Earth to a good approximation) amounts to asking questions like: can we find out its structure by finding out how long it takes for elastic waves (earthquake waves) to travel through it?

 

We introduced a novel method for dealing with these problems, in a mathematically precise  framework, which even allows one to localize to appropriate regions, such as near a portion of the surface of the body whose internal structure we are trying to understand. In particular, we have a complete mathematical result for the geodesic X-ray transform problem. We expect that under ongoing work we will be able to understand the boundary rigidity problem fully (currently we have a restriction of an isotropic sound speed).

 

Another part of this project was joint with Maarten de Hoop and Gunther Uhlmann. In this we analyzed propagation of singularities for solutions of the wave equation when sound speed (or general metric) has singularities of a certain type, which roughly speaking generalizes jumps in higher derivatives of the sound speed. (Such a change in the sound speed in practice would come from certain changes in material parameters.) Propagation of singularities is an aspect of geometric optics and describes how high frequency waves behave: the standard result, referred to above, is that they follow geodesics, which in empty space are straight lines. The sound speed singularities we study are of a relatively mild type, but the still cause reflection of waves. We showed, however, than in an appropriate (Sobolev) sense the reflected wave is more regular than the transmitted one, i.e. most of the wave travels `straight through' the location of the sound speed singularity. We expect to have application of this result to understanding what happens when waves reflect from a multitude of sound speed singularities, as is common in the Earth; this is work in progress.

 

A third part of this project was joint with de Hoop, Uhlmann and Wendt, in which we extended earlier work of these collaborators (in part with others) on numerical computation with Fourier integral operators (FIOs) (such as propagators, i.e. solution operators, for the wave equation) in a major way. Earlier work by de Hoop, Uhlmann and Wendt (in part with others) required the absence of caustics; these are roughly speaking geodesics emanating from a point which refocus, unlike straight lines. Caustics are very common for instance inside the Earth, and thus this was a major limitation. In our work the assumption on the lack of caustics is completely eliminated. We have also implemented this numerically, and checked that in practice this algorithm indeed works well.
